definition: accurate depiction of architectural forms with the aid of a ruler (technique of Chinese art)/picture created using this technique
to draw/picture/painting/CL:幅[fu2],張|张[zhang1]/classifier for paintings etc/variant of 劃|划[hua4]
Yang Ningshi (873-954) calligrapher of 5 dynasties period between Tang and Song
variant of 模擬|模拟[mo2 ni3]
Zhang Sengyou (active c. 490-540), one of the Four Great Painters of the Six Dynasties 六朝四大家
great calligraphy master/the Sage of Calligraphy, traditional reference to Wang Xizhi 王羲之[Wang2 Xi1 zhi1] (303-361)
Gu Kaizhi or Ku K'aichih (346-407), famous painter of Eastern Jin dynasty, one of the Four Great Painters of the Six Dynasties 六朝四大家
the Song dynasty (960-1279)/refers to the Northern (960-1127) and Southern Song (1128-1279)
lit. paper has become expensive in Luoyang (because everyone is making a copy of a popular story) (idiom)/fig. (of a product) to sell like hotcakes
standing above the common crowd (idiom); outstanding/excellent and unrivaled
blue-and-green landscape (genre of landscape painting originating in the Tang dynasty, in which blues and greens predominate)
Guangdong embroidery, one of the four major traditional styles of Chinese embroidery (the other three being 蘇繡|苏绣[Su1 xiu4], 湘繡|湘绣[Xiang1 xiu4] and 蜀繡|蜀绣[Shu3 xiu4])
